addressleaf.section:
To
e right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England

22 Oc
t
1595 M
r
Bodley to my L.
His Conference w
th
Mons
r
Barnevell
, and others.

page.lettertext:
fol.199r
May it please yo
r
good L. After so muche delibera-
tion, as in my last unto yo
r
L.
e 19 of this moneth
I reported at large,
e
States
deputed M
r
Barne-
velt, and
M
r
Vanderwerke
, w
t
e Greffier of their
college, to acquaint me w
t
e tenor of 2 severall
l
re
s, w
ch
they have written to her
Ma
tie
and my
LL.
of
e Councell
, tending onely to excuse
e protracting
of their answear to her Ma
ties
demaundes, to shewe
their curiousnesse alwaies in observing
e Contract,
to foresignifie
e dangers, if
e people should be told,
that her Ma
tie
would dissolve it, and to intreat her to
have patience, till their state will permitte,
at they may
use a shorter course, and give her better contentation.
They required me w
t
all, w
t
a vehement kinde of
speeche, That as I tendered
e advancement of her
Hig
es
service, and
e good correspondence between
e
two contreis, and as I knewe their allegations to be true
and unfained, and founde in conversation a harde
conceat
e people had of this demande of restitution,
I should seconde their l
re
s w
t
others of mine owne, and
deale in
at behalf w
t
all sinceritie, and roundnesse,
whereby her Hig
es
might forbeare from taking an
extreme or rigorous course against them. Wherunto
for an answear I signified againe,
at in all that they
desired, I had done my duty throughly, by my former
advertisments, and had faithfully delivered all their
reasons to her Ma
tie
in every suche material point, as
their l
re
s made remonstrance: all w
ch
notw
t
standing
her Hig
es
could not finde, but if so be they would endevo
r
to persuade
e Generalitie, and therein use their op-
portunities, w
t
at dexteritie and wisedome, as they are
wont in weightie causes,
ei might drawe them to the
fol.199v
paiment of some convenient portion: whereby perhaps she
might be moved, not to presse them for a while to any fur-
ther remboursement. But when nothing at all is presen-
ted unto her, considering her long and chargeable succo
rs
,
and considering her present domestical necessities, with
other manifold occasions, of w
ch
ei had bin by me infor-
med at full, and they of themselves could make
e reck-
ning well enough, it could not choose but engender some
notable alienation. Moreover for my self I had bin
charged expressely, not to yelde, or to hearcken to any
dilatorie answear: for w
ch
they were not to attend my
conveiance of their l
re
s, nor any other office,
at might
any way seeme to favo
r
their present resolution. Of
at
w
ch
passed too and fro to this effect and
e like, they
made relation to th eir college: who for ought I can perceave
goe onward w
t
their purpose, to send away those l
re
s, which I
thinke they will consigne to their Agent
M
r
Caron
.
The Councel of Estate was very earnestly bent, to have
sent unto her Ma
tie
some men of good account, and the
states, I am persuaded, had folowed
at counsail, but
at
ei staied their proceeding upon my prohibition.
And
thus remaining uncertaine, w
at
course of further dealing
will be pleasing to her Ma
tie
I will attend in
at behalf
yo
r
L. good direction, and take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. 22 Oc
t
95.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
